ofx:section.ofx:title: Data Structure
ofx:section.ofx:paragraph: The data structure to of the core elements to manage maps and layers is shown in Figure .

media:image.ofx:title: Data Structure for Managing Maps and Layers

ofx:section.ofx:paragraph: There are four entities used for the data structure. The Category is only used to categorize different layer into thematic areas. The concept of specifying what should be shown on the map is based on layers. A layer is the smallest unit that can be set to be shown or not shown. The GIS component is working with maps and further geospatial information coming from servers offering their services via Web Mapping Service (WMS) and Web Feature Service (WFS), this is also reflected in the data model.

l:item.name: Service
l:item.ofx:paragraph: A Service characterizes a Web Mapping Service (WMS) or Web Feature Service (WFS) service by itâ€™s URL. A service can offer multiple layers.

l:item.name: Layer
l:item.ofx:paragraph: Each service can provide different unique Layers identified by their code (e.g. roads, infrastructures). It can optionally be marked as a "temporal" layer. A temporal layer includes information for different moments in time, e.g. the clouds over europe for every five minutes.

l:item.name: View
l:item.ofx:paragraph: The View is the binding between the map and the layer. This entity stores additional default properties like the order number, the default visibility or default legend information.

l:item.name: Map
l:item.ofx:paragraph: A map, or better a thematic map, is a composition of layers in a defined order. As stated above, layers are data-wise encapsulated in View entities, that hold information about their visibility, their ordering number (e.g. roads are shown on top of terrain) and the legend for this layer. The Views, along with a ViewPort (including information about the center of the map, its boundaries and the resolution), are all the information needed to display a map.
